Comments_List: I learned a good mix of information theory and phonology--mostly complexity theory as related to phonology. I developed a working knowledge of the kind of research being done in phonology from an information-theoretic viewpoint.
Learned some basics of information theory and how it's been applied to phonology.

This course was an excellent chance to learn about information theory, which is something I never would have encountered otherwise. Perhaps its only weakness is that we didn't spend much time working through the actual math in class, but this was possible through the readings and doesn't need to happen in a seminar format. I also thought the freedom to pursue the final research project was a strength.
I would recommend this course to a student who's interested in phonology and enjoys getting a bit quantitative.
Yes, this was a super cool and very new-to-me way of thinking about phonology.
